Submodule module1

In this package we have the module arithmetic_operations that represents the basic arithmetic operations. That module is also what we named the documentation of the code of the module. On the other hand, this module show the functional documentation of the package.

Functional Documentation

Below, you will find the functional documentation of the package module1.

ArithmeticOperations Class Documentation

  • ArithmeticOperations Class

    • Initialization

    • Methods to use after Initialization

    • Example Usage

ArithmeticOperations Class

The ArithmeticOperations class provides a simple interface for performing basic arithmetic operations, including addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division. It is designed to handle integer operands and offers a convenient way to perform common mathematical calculations.

Initialization

To create an instance of the ArithmeticOperations class, provide two integer values as parameters during initialization:

calculator = ArithmeticOperations(10, 2)

The constructor validates that both provided values are integers. If either value is not an integer, a ValueError will be raised.

Methods to use after Initialization

The ArithmeticOperations class provides the following methods.

  • add() Adds the two initialized numbers and returns the result.

result = calculator.add()

  • subtract() Subtracts the second initialized number from the first and returns the result.

result = calculator.subtract()

  • multiply() Multiplies the two initialized numbers and returns the result.

result = calculator.multiply()

  • divide() Divides the first initialized number by the second. Raises a ValueError if attempting to divide by zero.

result = calculator.divide()
Example Usage

Here is an example demonstrating the usage of the ArithmeticOperations class:

1# Valid initialization
2calculator = ArithmeticOperations(10, 2)
3print(f"Addition: {calculator.add()}")
4print(f"Subtraction: {calculator.subtract()}")
5print(f"Multiplication: {calculator.multiply()}")
6print(f"Division: {calculator.divide()}")

Note

The example showcases both valid and invalid initializations, providing a clear understanding of how the class handles integer validation.

Enjoy using the ArithmeticOperations class for your basic arithmetic needs!
